title: 111_s2834
content: The Act may be cited as the "Security Clearance Modernization and Reporting Act of 2009". Definitions are provided in the Act. The Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004 is amended to redesignate paragraphs and clarify the title. The Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004 is amended to clarify the definition of adjudication in background investigations for various purposes related to Federal Government employment and access to information. The Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004 is amended to define "classified information" as data requiring protection against unauthorized disclosure and "continuous evaluation" as ongoing background checks for individuals with access to classified information. The term 'contractor' refers to individuals who are not employees of an agency but perform work for or on behalf of an agency, including subcontractors and consultants. 'Contractor employee fitness' is defined as fitness based on character and conduct for work as a contractor employee. The term 'federally controlled facilities' and 'federally controlled information systems' are defined in guidance related to the Federal Information Security Management Act of 2002 and Homeland Security Presidential Directive 12. 'Logical access' refers to regular access to federally controlled information systems. The term 'physical access' refers to regular access to federally controlled facilities. 'Sensitive position' is any position designated as such under Executive Order 10450. 'Suitability' is defined in part 731 of title 5, Code of Federal Regulations. SEC. 3. SECURITY CLEARANCE AND SUITABILITY DETERMINATION REPORTING. Extension of reporting requirements under the Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004 until 2 years after the removal of security clearance items from the High-Risk List or 2017. Amendment to reports on security clearance review processes to include time required for initial clearance applications by investigative agencies. The curr_chunk discusses the timeframes required for security clearance processes, including initiating investigations, conducting investigations, adjudicating requests, making determinations, and notifying individuals and employers. It also mentions the different types of security clearances such as Secret, Top Secret, and Top Secret with Special Program Access. The curr_chunk discusses Special Program Access for civilian employees, members of the Armed Forces, and contractor employees, including conducting investigations for suitability determinations. The curr_chunk provides a listing of agencies accepting security clearance background investigations, progress on implementing strategic and IT plans. The curr_chunk introduces the creation of the Security Clearance and Suitability Performance Accountability Council under the Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004. The Security Clearance and Suitability Performance Accountability Council (referred to as the 'Council') is established under the Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004. The Deputy Director for Management, Office of Management and Budget, serves as the Chair with authority over the Council's functions. A Vice Chair is selected by the Chair, and membership includes the Chair and a senior officer from the Office of the Director of National Intelligence. The Security Clearance and Suitability Performance Accountability Council, established under the Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004, includes members from various agencies. The Council's duties involve aligning suitability, security, and investigative processes, overseeing IT requirements, and developing tools and techniques. The Security Clearance and Suitability Performance Accountability Council oversees the development of techniques and tools for background investigations, ensures reciprocal recognition of clearances among agencies, shares best practices, and holds agencies accountable for security processes. The Security Clearance and Suitability Performance Accountability Council ensures agencies recognize clearances granted by others and may assign duties related to investigations, contractor fitness, and access eligibility. The Security Clearance and Suitability Performance Accountability Council oversees clearances for access to classified information and sensitive positions. SEC. 5. STRATEGIC PLAN FOR REFORM. Amends Title III of the Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act to include a new section on Security Clearance and Suitability Reform Strategic Plan. The Security Clearance and Suitability Performance Accountability Council must develop a strategic plan within 90 days of the Security Clearance Modernization and Reporting Act of 2009. The plan should address issues with security clearances and outline corrective actions, including mission goals, performance measures, and a communication strategy. The Security Clearance and Suitability Performance Accountability Council must develop a strategic plan within 90 days of the Security Clearance Modernization and Reporting Act of 2009. The plan should address issues with security clearances, roles and responsibilities for agencies, and long-term funding requirements. The plan will be submitted to Congress and reviewed by the Government Accountability Office. SEC. 6. INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY STRATEGY. The Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004 is amended to include a new section on Information Technology Strategy. The Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004 is amended to include a new section on Information Technology Strategy. The Director of the Office of Management and Budget must submit an information technology strategy to expedite security clearance processes and verify information. The new section on Information Technology Strategy in the Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004 requires a description of the IT needed for security clearance and suitability investigations, supporting systems, transmission of investigation files, agency adjudications, continuous evaluations, and a single repository for all agency determinations. The curr_chunk describes the efforts and plans of agencies and departments in the United States to ensure reciprocal recognition of access to classified information, including cost estimates and personnel allocation. The curr_chunk provides a description of the schedule for carrying out the strategy submitted under subsection (a). SEC. 7. TECHNICAL AND CLERICAL AMENDMENTS. The table of contents in the Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004 is amended to include new sections related to security clearances and information technology strategy.
